clinicalAtRiskGroupsText:
The links below provide detailed information on the clinical rules that determine who is eligible for the booster.

The rules apply to:
- children aged 5 to 15 years within specific clinical at-risk groups
- adults ages 16 years and over

The clinical at-risk groups are:
demographicsText: All those aged 5 years or older in the clinical risk groups shown in Tables 3 and 4 of the Green Book.
description: The autumn booster is being offered to those at high risk of the complications of infection. The booster should help to reduce their risk of being admitted to hospital.
disclaimerText: The information provided outlines CaaS's approach to delivering this cohort using established methodologies. It highlights any differences from the clinical criteria in the Green Book and associated assumptions.
name: Autumn booster vaccinations
summary:
NHS England commissioned Cohort as a Service (CaaS) to identify people that were eligible for the autumn booster vaccination.
To be eligible, they needed to be:
- children aged 5 to 15 years
- adults aged 16 years and over
- in defined clinical risk groups shown in tables 3 and 4 of the [Green Book]( https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/)
CaaS developed specific rules based on the conditions in the Green Book and used clinical data to identify people who met the rules.
The data collected helped to:
- contact or remind people to receive their  autumn booster
- focus protection on those at clinical risk
- report and monitor on the autumn booster campaign

conditionGroups.name: Asplenia or dysfunction of the spleen
conditionGroups.nonDigitalPathwayOverview:
If a person receives care from another healthcare provider, for example a hospital, specialist, or community clinic, their GP record is not automatically updated.
If a person’s GP record is not up-to-date when creating a cohort, they may not be included in the digital pathway.
This may result in a person not receiving the invite for their vaccination.
If you believe you’re eligible for a vaccination, but have not received your invite, then [visit the NHS website on the vaccination](https://www.nhs.uk/) for more information.
conditionGroups.ruleLogicOverview:
The table below shows the clinical rules used to determine who should be contacted or reminded to receive their autumn booster vaccinations based on specific medical conditions.
These conditions are detailed in the [Green Book](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/).

conditions.description: People with asplenia or dysfunction of the spleen
conditions.nonDigitalPathwayText:
There is no clinically agreed list of these conditions, so the code clusters may be incomplete.
This means that some people with these conditions may not be included in the CaaS digital pathway.

conditionGroups.name: Chronic heart disease
conditionGroups.nonDigitalPathwayOverview:
If a person receives care from another healthcare provider, for example a hospital, specialist, or community clinic, their GP record is not automatically updated.
If a person’s GP record is not up-to-date when creating a cohort, they may not be included in the digital pathway.
This may result in a person not receiving the invite for their vaccination.
If you believe you’re eligible for a vaccination, but have not received your invite, then [visit the NHS website on the COVID-19 vaccination](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/covid-19/covid-19-vaccination/getting-a-covid-19-vaccine/) for more information.

conditions.description:
People requiring regular medication and/or follow-up for ischaemic heart disease
This includes:
- atrial fibrillation
- peripheral vascular disease
- a history of venous thromboembolism
conditions.nonDigitalPathwayText: All conditions are included in the CaaS digital pathway

codes.shortDescription: Dialysis therapy started by renal service (finding)
Hypertensive heart AND chronic kidney disease stage 3 (disorder)

clinicalAtRiskGroupsText:
The condition groups listed below provide detailed information on who is included and excluded from the digital cohort.

The list is not exhaustive, and decisions should be based on clinical judgement.

The clinical at-risk groups are:
commissioner: NHS-E vaccination programme's Tech and Data workstream, delivered by NHS Digital.
demographicsText: All people aged 6 months or older that are in the clinical risk groups shown in the Green Book.
description: The vaccination is recommended for all people over 6 months of age. It provides protection to those who are at higher risk of serious illness.
disclaimerText: The information provided outlines CaaS's approach to delivering this cohort using established methodologies. It highlights any differences from the clinical criteria in the Green Book and associated assumptions.
name: Vaccinations 2022 to 2023
summary:
NHS England commissioned Cohorting as a Service (CaaS) to identify people that were eligible for the 2022 to 2023 vaccination.
To be eligible, they needed to be:
- 6 months of age or older
- in defined clinical risk groups shown in the [Green Book](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/)
CaaS developed specific rules based on the conditions in the Green Book and used clinical data to identify people who met those rules.
The data collected helped to:
- contact or remind people to receive their vaccination between 1 September 2022 and 31 March 2023
- focus protection on those at a clinical risk
- monitor the number of people who received the vaccination

conditionGroups.name: Chronic heart disease (2022 to 2023)
conditionGroups.nonDigitalPathwayOverview:
If a person receives care from another healthcare provider, for example a hospital, specialist, or community clinic, their GP record is not automatically updated.
If a person’s GP record is not up-to-date when creating a cohort, they may not be included in the digital pathway.
This may result in a person not receiving the invite for their vaccination.
If you believe you’re eligible for a vaccination, but have not received your invite, then [visit the NHS website on the vaccination](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/vaccinations/) for more information.
conditionGroups.ruleLogicOverview:
The table below shows the clinical rules used to determine who should be contacted or reminded to receive their vaccination based on specific medical conditions.
These conditions are detailed in the [Green Book](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/).

conditions.description:
People with:
- congenital heart disease with cardiac complications
- chronic heart failure
- regular medication and/or follow-up for ischaemic heart disease
conditions.nonDigitalPathwayText: All conditions are included in the CaaS digital pathway

conditionGroups.nonDigitalPathwayOverview:
If a person receives care from another healthcare provider, for example a hospital, specialist, or community clinic, their GP record is not automatically updated.
If a person’s GP record is not up-to-date when creating a cohort, they may not be included in the digital pathway.
This may result in a person not receiving the invite for their vaccination.
If you believe you’re eligible for a vaccination, but have not received your invite, then [visit the NHS website](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/vaccinations/) for more information.
conditionGroups.ruleLogicOverview:
The table below shows the clinical rules used to determine who should be contacted or reminded to receive their vaccination based on specific medical conditions.
These conditions are detailed in the [Green Book](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/).

conditions.description:
People with:
- chronic kidney disease at stage 3, 4 or 5
- chronic kidney failure
- nephrotic syndrome
- kidney transplant
conditions.nonDigitalPathwayText: All conditions are included in the CaaS digital pathway

codes.shortDescription: Laparoscopic transplant of kidney using robotic assistance (procedure)
Chronic kidney disease stage 1 with proteinuria (disorder)
